description.narrative: The programme will support GoU to strengthen; policy response on integration, provision of incentives & deterrents measures; national policy implementation capacities; LGs to build a strong community resilient to climate change and other disasters

participating-org.narrative: UGA Office of the Prime Mster
UN DEPT OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Output 1 1.1: Number of target institutions that have developed, policies, strategies, and budgets that integrate sustainable energy, natural resource and land management, biodiversity, climate change and DRR mitigation and resilience initiatives. 1.2: Percentage of sectors and institutions integrating climate change mitigation, disaster-risk recovery and resilience into development plans and budgets. 1.3: Number of districts where local climate change adaptation fund is established and operational to provide financial resources for climate change adaptation interventions.
Output 2: 2.1: Existence of harmonized functional national climate information and early warning system. 2.2: Extent to which a system exists to access, deliver, monitor, report and verify the use of environmental and climate finance. 2.3: Number of national/sub-national development and key sectoral plans that explicitly address disaster and/or climate risk management being implemented, dis aggregated by those which are gender responsive.
Output 3: 3.1: Number of functional platforms established to engage populations at all levels for sustainable environment and natural resources, CC-R and energy access 3.2: Number of gender responsive pilot and demonstration projects/business models adopted or scaled up by national partners
Output 4: 4.1 Percentage of target population with access to early warning (including climate information), dis aggregated by gender (% of women and of the targeted population have access to early warning (including climate information), dis aggregated by gender).

comment.narrative:
Output 1: By end 2018, targeted MDAs have adequate technical, functional and financial capacity to integrate and operationalize NRM and climate change mitigation policies and strategies, including: (a) execution of priority gender-responsive investments that increase energy access and consumption efficiency and promote low-carbon and renewable modern energy services; and (b) scale-up of climate change mitigation / adaptation and disaster-risk management strategies 1.1: 63 institutions developed, policies, strategies, and budgets that integrate sustainable energy, natural resource and land management, biodiversity, climate change and DRR mitigation and resilience initiatives (2013 - Sector review reports) 1.2: 20% of sectors and institutions integrating climate change mitigation, disaster-risk recovery and resilience into development plans and budgets (2013 - National climate change finance analysis report; hazard, risk, & vulnerability profile reports) 1.3: Zero districts where local climate change adaptation fund is established and operational to provide financial resources for climate change adaptation interventions (2015 - MoLG data) Output 2: By 2018, MDAs with adequate technical, operational and financial capacities to implement CCR/DRR policies and regulatory frameworks 2.1: There is no harmonized functional national climate information and early warning system (2014 - NECOC) 2.2: There is no existence of a system to access, deliver, monitor, report and verify the use of environmental and climate finance (2013 - Overseas Development Institute reports) 2.3: 10 national/sub-national development and key sectoral plans that explicitly address disaster and/or climate risk management being implemented, disaggregated by those which are gender responsive (2013 - NECOC)
Output 3: By 2018, MDAs with adequate technical, technological, operational and financial capacities to engage the private sector, LGs and CSOs to deliver on gender responsive CCR/DRR innovations 3.1:

Output 1 1.1: Number of target institutions that have developed, policies, strategies, and budgets that integrate sustainable energy, natural resource and land management, biodiversity, climate change and DRR mitigation and resilience initiatives. 1.2: Percentage of sectors and institutions integrating climate change mitigation, disaster-risk recovery and resilience into development plans and budgets. 1.3: Number of districts where local climate change adaptation fund is established and operational to provide financial resources for climate change adaptation interventions.
Output 2: 2.1: Existence of harmonized functional national climate information and early warning system. 2.2: Extent to which a system exists to access, deliver, monitor, report and verify the use of environmental and climate finance. 2.3: Number of national/sub-national development and key sectoral plans that explicitly address disaster and/or climate risk management being implemented, dis aggregated by those which are gender responsive.

1.1.2 The National Climate change Bill was approved by Parliament 1.1.3 Climate change and Disaster Risk Reduction were integrated into NDPIII 1.2.3 GoU signed the international charter space and to ensure sustainability of access to UNOSAT Data 1.2.4 The National Disaster Response and Recovery Plan was developed 1.3.5 National Planning Authority carried out Climate Change compliance assessments for sector development plans. Local government sectoral / technical heads of departments of newly created districts (Kagadi, Kakumiro, Rukiga, Rubanda, Bunyangabu, Pakwach, Omoro, Namisindwa and Butebo) were trained on the integration of climate change in district development planning and budgeting. 2.2.1 The U-NIEWS monthly bulletin that notifies MDAs, INGO’s, NGO’s, Farmers, UN Agencies and public on probable disasters which may occur without warning based on climate and weather forecast was produced and disseminated. 2.2.3 capacity of MDAs on NDA procedures and financing opportunities especially GCF accreditation and proposal development was built by Ministry of Finance and NPA.

Result 1.1 Enhanced policy, legal and regulatory framework for climate change response and disaster risk reduction 1.1.1 Print copies of the National Climate Change Law Result 1.3. Climate change response and Disaster Risk Reduction integrated and mainstreamed in policies, plans and budgets of MDAs and local governments. 1.3.1 Finalize and launch the National Vulnerability and Risk Atlas of Uganda.
Result 2.2 A strengthened and integrated functional climate information, early warning and response system established. 2.2.1. U-NEWS monthly Bulletin Developed and Disseminated 2.2.2 Undertake data rescue and digitization of the historical data (1930-1960).
4.1. Mass Public awareness created on CCR, early warning and disaster risk reduction and technologies 4.1.1 Produce and disseminate Publicity and visibility (documentary, press coverage)
Output 7. 1: Enhanced Coordination Capacity for response and recovery from floods and Landslides 7.1.1 Enhance response coordination mechanisms at national, district and community level 7.1.2 Develop multi sectoral tools for data analysis and visualization. Output 7. 2: Multi sector assessments to determine early recovery needs response measures 7.2.1 Conduct joint assessments to determine specific community recovery needs to enhance resilience of the affected population Output 7. 3:Resilience and early recovery framework developed 7.3.2 Develop an early recovery and Resilience Framework
Output 8.Improved coordination of multi-hazard induced disasters preparedness, response, and recovery 8.1 Enhance Multi-sectoral Coordination Capacity of National (NECOC) and Local Governments(DECOC) for integrated multi-hazard Response 8.2 Strengthen Assessment Capacity for NECOC 8.3 Enhance Disaster Risk Communication (National to Local and vis-versa) 8.4 Improve Border Surveillance and Tracking

1.3.1 Finalization of the National Vulnerability and Risk Atlas was done 2.2.1 UNIEWS was produced and distributed every month 2.2.2 Data rescue and digitization of historical data (1930-1960) was not done. 4.1.1 Two documentaries and several visibility materials were done about early warning and press coverage of the International Day for Disaster Reduction (IDRR). 7.1.1 A National Disaster Response Framework was developed and toll free lines established to enhance response coordination mechanisms at national, district and community level 7.1.2 Multi-sectoral tools were developed for mapping, collection, analysis of data and visualization of information concerning disasters and multi-hazard early warning 7.2.1 A joint assessment was done to determine the impact of floods and multiple disasters and the recovery needs were identified for each of the projects affected 7.3.2 A National Business continuity plan in the event of disasters was developed as part of the Resilience Framework 8.1 Capacity of NECOC was enhanced through equipping NECOD with data capturing equipment like drones and computers for data management, training users at NECOC and in DECOCs 8.2 Assessment capacity of NECOC was strengthened through equipment instalments at District level and training users on GIS, use of the drones and providing all time solar powered stations for data management 8.3 Disaster Risk Communication was enhanced through engagement of media houses, televisions and radios, to share information about how NECOD works but also share disaster risk information regularly 8.4 Development of tracking tools for borderline surveillance was not done because of time and resources.

Output 1.1 Enhanced policy, legal and regulatory framework for climate change response and disaster risk reduction 1.1.1 Finalize review of National Disaster Preparedness and Management policy and drafting of the National Disaster Preparedness and management bill 1.1.2 Institutionalizing the gender responsive National Climate Change bill
1.2 Government meets regional and global commitments for environment, CCR/DRR and influences policy, financing 1.2.1 Facilitate inclusive preparation and participation processes at COP25 on CC
1.3. Climate change response and Disaster Risk Reduction integrated and mainstreamed in policies, plans and budgets of MDAs and local governments. 1.3.1 Finalize the National Vulnerability and Risk Atlas of Uganda 1.3.2 Mainstreaming of CCA into agricultural sector
2.2 A strengthened and integrated functional climate information, early warning and response system established 2.2.1. U-NEWS monthly Bulletin Developed and Disseminated- 2.2.3 Enhance dissemination and use of climate information through champions and learning
Out put 2.4 A national system for tracking and reporting on environment and DRR financing and expenditure strengthened 2.4.2 Baseline expenditure review foe selected sectors to inform allocations and policy direction
Output 2.5 Capacities of cities strengthened for resilient development 2.5.1 Disseminate CC profiles and finalize national CC mainstreaming guidelines for urban planning
Output 3.1. Functional partnerships and platforms for implementing CCR/DRR innovative low carbon(green) technologies established between MDAs, LGs, CSOs and private sector 3.1.1 Conduct the 2nd Climate change symposium Out put 3.2 3.2.1 Facilitate youth engagement for DRR and SDG delivery 3.2.2 Conduct Climate and DRR challenge with media houses
Output 4.1 Mass public awareness created for CCR, early warning and DRR and technologies 4.1.1 Facilitate LGs to develop community based disaster resilience and emergency response plans for selected high risk areas 4.1.2 Support observance of the International Day for DRR

Out put 1.1 DPM policy was finalized A gender responsive climate change bill was finalized and ready for presentation to parliament A Regulatory Impact Assessment (RIA) was conducted on the DPM Bill to verify the need for the disaster law.
Output 1.2 A national position on Climate change was developed in an inclusive workshop Uganda was represented at Global Platform for DRR conference where they presented Uganda’s progress on DRR, shared lessons and strengthened collaborations with other countries Output 1.3 The NVRAU was completed and is ready for printing 29 out of the 47 developed District Multi hazard HRV profiles were finalized Guidelines to mainstream CC in Agriculture sector were disseminated in Karamoja and Central regions, and CSOs to provide practical, step-by-step guidance on how to mainstream climate change adaptation and mitigation in their planning and decision-making processes.
Output 2.2.1 Ten (10) U-NIEWS monthly bulletins were distributed to MDAs, INGO’s, NGO’s, Farmers, UN Agencies and public on probable disasters and on climate and weather forecast. In this respect , Uganda won a GEO-SDG award in relation to SDG -1 because of the contribution of the UNIEWS in early warning.
2.2.3 Champions were identified and trained by UNMA Output 2.4 A Climate Public Expenditure and Institutional Review (CPEIR) was planned but not completed by Min of Finance
Output 2.5 Urban CC profiles were disseminated to 25 DLGs to be used for future planning Guidelines to mainstream CC and DRR into the Urban planning sub-sector were finalized and disseminated to 30district local governments in northern, West Nile and Western regions Seven(7) DLGs were supported to mainstream CC into their DDPs, but activity was not finalized
Output 3.1 A benchmarking visit was made to Zambia by UNMA improving the dissemination and application of weather and climate information The 2nd National CC symposium was conducted(360 participants; 255 female) Output 3.2 The youth conference and the SDG run were conducted to create awareness on CC and DRR The Media Climate Challenge was conducted to equip young journalists and mainstream journalists with skills and knowledge to practice journalism that drives social change in the climate change and DRR sector
Output 4.1 Village Disaster Management Committee (VDMC) and Village Resilient and Preparedness Plans (VRAP) were developed for selected high risk villages in Bulambuli and Manafwa districts. The VDMC were linked to the DDMC of respective districts and resource needs were identified for improved preparedness and response, during and post disaster situations at villages. The IDRR was not cerebrated as planned
